Graphical abstract In this research, selective catalytic oxidation was applied to remove high-concentration hydrogen sulfide in landfill gas. The removal efficiency of H2S was the best with V/TiO2 catalyst produced by wet impregnation among. The optimum vanadium content was 10 %. In addition, selective conversion to elemental sulfur and generation of SO2 could be controlled by adjusting O2/H2S ratio. The larger the cell per square inch that affected the performance of the honeycomb-type catalyst, the greater the removal efficiency of H2S according to increase in specific surface area. An analysis of long-term performance of the honeycomb-type catalyst with landfill gas including CH4 and CO2 revealed that more than 90 % of H2S was removed. In addition, the performance of the catalyst could be recovered by thermal regeneration. Considering that the performance of a catalyst can be recovered for durability and regeneration, V/TiO2 coated honeycomb-type catalyst can be used in the actual process. Keywords V/TiO2 Hydrogen sulfide Landfill gas Selective catalytic oxidation Honeycomb Regeneration 1 Introduction Landfill gas (LFG) generated during the process of burying waste is composed of over 90 % of methane (CH4) and carbon dioxide (CO2) with small amounts of other substances such as nitrogen (N2), oxygen (O2) and hydrogen sulfide (H2S) [1]. While methane contributes to global warming, it can also be used as an energy source. Its value is especially high in energy recovery and response to climate change as well as in facilities where renewable energy can be secured [2,3]. However, landfill gas contains impurities such as siloxane, ammonia, and H2S that interfere with methane production. These are the source of odor. Therefore, pretreatment facility is required to produce high-purity methane [4,5]. The production of impurities in landfill gas is known to be due to sulfate ion contained in construction waste [6]. Under anaerobic conditions sulfate reducing bacteria (SRB) can reduce sulfate ions into H2S. Depending on the surrounding environment, a high concentration up to 4 % (v/v) of H2S can be produced [7]. A high-concentration H2S can lead to higher overhead expense of the pretreatment facility and deterioration of power plants [8]. A high-concentration H2S in landfill gas also causes corrosion of the equipment and secondary environmental pollution by emitting more SO2 during combustion. As H2S is one of the most ill-smelling substances with negative effect on the human body, it is essential to effectively remove it from the pretreatment facility [4,5]. H2S removal technology includes physico-chemical treatment such as adsorption and membrane or biological treatment using microorganisms [9–11]. However, their applications are limited because physico-chemical treatment has low H2S removal efficiency while biologic treatment is highly dependent on environmental changes. THIOPAQ Process is another option to remove H2S. In this process, H2S is absorbed to chemical solution to react with microorganisms and convert to sulfide. However, this technology has limitations in processing capacity, causing overload and requiring wastewater treatment [12]. Recently, CLAUS process has been introduced to solve these problems [13]. Selective Catalytic Oxidation (SCO) has been applied in the latter part of the CLAUS process [14–17]. SCO is a reaction that allows direct oxidization from H2S to elemental sulfur. It is an exothermic reaction that is different from the existing technology in that over 99 % of H2S can be removed at a relatively low temperature (150−200 °C). Eqs. (1)–(3) show SCO reactions of H2S: (1) Main reaction H2S + 0.5O2 → 1/nSn + H2O △H = −222 kJ/mole (2) Side reaction H2S + 1.5O2 → SO2 + H2O △H = −518 kJ/mole (3) 2H2S + SO2 → 3/nSn + 2H2O △H = −77 kJ/mole These reactions are determined by O2/H2S ratio. As SO2, produced in the side reaction of Eq. (2), is an environmental pollutant and reduces the durability of the catalysts, it is necessary to suppress the progress of this side reaction [15]. To control SO2 production, studies have been performed on different types and contents of active substances as well as various types of supports and additives of catalysts [14–20]. In previous studies, V2O5 has shown the highest activity among other different kinds of active substances [17–19]. The higher the content of V2O5 and reaction temperature, the higher the removal efficiency of H2S and SO2 production. Previous studies have applied V2O5 to various supports of metallic oxides (ɣ-Al2O3, ZrO2, SiO2, TiO2, etc.) [20]. It is known that TiO2 catalyst has the best performance among various supports of metallic oxides [21]. Some metal organic frameworks, zeolites, carbon, and composites that are based on these materials have also been used to remove H2S through selective catalytic oxidation [22]. Removal of H2S from CLAUS process for SCO of H2S has also been studied. Furthermore, studies have been conducted by adding additives such as Sb and Mo to improve [23,24]. Although many studies have been performed on biogas, most of them have dealt with low concentrations of H2S and powder type which would be difficult to be applied to actual process [25–29]. Those applied for the actual process include research on the production of a granular catalyst based on FeOx and that on the production of a catalyst coated with GFC (Glass Fiber Catalyst). However, the performance of the catalyst was as low as less than 50 % at low temperature (170 °C) [25,26]. Table 1 shows the trends in the catalysts used for examining the selective oxidation of H2S, which are V2O5/TiO2, V2O5/Fe2O3, V2O5/CeO2, V2O5/Zr, Fe/Al, Fe2O3/SiC, TiVOx, 2Fe-2Ce, Nb/Fe, and others [30–41]. Honeycomb has been applied to various processes. SCR process that treats NOx is a typical example, especially catalysts coated with vanadium, has been widely used. Since honeycomb is intended to be applied to the actual process, studies on coating catalysts and choosing supports have been mostly carried out. Recently, some studies on the application of honeycomb to SCO of H2S have also been reported [27–29,42]. Ismagilov et al. (1999) have applied an MgCr2O4/Al2O3 catalyst [43]. Palma et al. (2016) have used a catalyst with honeycomb based on ceria/zirconia coated with vanadium oxide and achieved excellent performance even at low temperatures [16]. However, the concentration of target gas is too low at 500 ppm. In addition, studies on coating method and performance are limited. As for SCO of H2S, sulfur and SO2 known to cause durability degradation of the catalyst are contained in the final product in high concentration. Thus, it is important to consider durability and regeneration of catalysts [14]. Studies on durability and regeneration of catalysts according to SO2 production are mainly carried out with air-assisted high-temperature treatment [44–46]. Studies on durability and regeneration of catalysts according to sulfur generation are insufficient. Therefore, the objective of this study was to optimize powder-type V/TiO2 catalysts to remove high-concentration H2S and explore the performance, durability, and regeneration of V/TiO2-coated honeycomb-type catalysts with landfill gas. In the optimization study, removal efficiencies of H2S were compared by catalyst production method, O2/H2O ratio, and vanadium content based on TiO2. In addition, the performance of V/TiO2 catalyst was evaluated according to reaction temperature of landfill gas containing CH4 and CO2. The effect of CPSI (cell per square inch) and the amount of V/TiO2 on the performance of V/TiO2-coated honeycomb-type catalyst was also explored. This research also discussed the durability and regeneration method of honeycomb-type catalyst when it was exposed to landfill gas containing high-concentration H2S for a long time. Therefore, this research aims to investigate the applicability of V/TiO2-coated honeycomb-type catalysts in the practical process where high-concentration H2S is produced. 2 Experiments 2.1 Catalyst preparation The active substance of the catalyst was vanadium. As for support, TiO2 (G-3, Cristal Global Co.) was employed. The wet impregnation method of producing the catalyst was carried out as follows with reference to Kwon et al.(2013) [47]. After ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3, Aldrich Chemical Co.) was dissolved in distilled water and heated to 60 °C, oxalic acid ((COOH)2, Aldrich Chemical Co.) was added to adjust pH to prevent increase in solubility of vanadium precursors and elution of vanadium. The slurry containing vanadium and TiO2 was stirred for over one hour. Water was then evaporated at 65 °C using a rotary vacuum evaporator. Powder-type V/TiO2 catalyst was produced by drying in a 105 °C drying furnace for 24 h followed by calcining in a calcination furnace at a heating rate of 10 °C/min with heat treatment temperature of 400 °C and 4 h of air atmosphere. To coat cordierite honeycomb (Honeycomb, Ceracomb Co.) with V/TiO2, dip coatings was employed. In the dip-coating method, 10 V / TiO2-impregnation powder was mixed with distilled water at a 1:10 wt ratio, and 10 wt% LUDOX AS-40(Sigma-aldrich Co.) was used as a binder and stirred. At this time, the stirring was performed for 15 min of magnetic-stirring and 30 min of ultrasonic stirring, and then dip coating was performed while continuously magnetic-stirring. Table 2 shows physical properties of four types of honeycomb used in this research. Four CPSIs (50, 100, 200 and 300) were used for the honeycomb. The prepared V/TiO2 coating solution was coated 70, 100 g L−1 based on the honeycomb volume. When the targeted amount was coated, it was calcined at a heating rate of 10 °C/min with a heat treatment temperature of 400 °C and 4 h of air atmosphere [47,48]. Fig. 1 shows V/TiO2-coated honeycomb-type catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst activity tests Activity test of the prepared catalyst was performed in a reactor consisting of a gas injection part, a catalyst reaction part, a sulfur recovery part, and a measuring part. Fig. 2 shows components of the laboratory plant. To minimize effect of the catalyst’s uniformity and pressure loss, powder-type catalyst was sieved to 40–50 mesh size. The honeycomb-type catalyst was selected based on the size of 1cc and filled to a quartz tube. N2, O2, and H2S were supplied to the reactor and 10 % H2S/CO2, CH4, CO2, N2 and AIR were injected through MFC (Mass Flow Controller, MKS Co.) when forming landfill gas. The temperature of the reactor was controlled using a K-type thermocouple on the top of the fixed-bed (PID Controller, Nova Co.). For the measuring part, concentrations of H2S and SO2 were measured with a detector tube 4HH (Gas Tec. Co.) and a detector tube 5 M (Gas Tec. Co.), respectively. For the quarts tube at the rear end of the reactor, the temperature was controlled to be higher than 200 °C using a heating band to prevent condensation by sulfur. The performance of the catalyst used in this research was confirmed by H2S conversion with Eq. (4) and outlet SO2 concentration. (4) H 2 S c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = [ H 2 S ] i n - [ H 2 S ] o u t [ H 2 S ] i n × 100 2.3 Catalyst characterization To check the surface of the product after reaction with the catalyst, a field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) (S-4800, Hitachi Co.) was used. Elemental distribution of the product was confirmed through an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analysis. Specific surface area was measured using ASAP 2010C (Micromeritics Co.) and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) formula. Crystal structure and crystallinity of the catalyst surface were studied through an XRD (X-ray diffraction) (Mini Flex2, Rigaku Co.) analysis. Cu Kα (λ = 1.5056 Å) was used as radiation source and 2θ was measured within the range of 20-80° at an injection rate of 6°/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 H2S oxidation performance and effects of powder type vanadium catalyst This research compared removal efficiency of H2S according to the production method of vanadium catalysts, O2/H2S ratio, and vanadium content. The form of vanadium bond depends on the production method. To explore the removal efficiency of H2S according to this, the following catalysts were used: powder-type V2O5 (V2O5 powder), V/TiO2-mixed (a simple mixture of TiO2 and vanadium), and V/TiO2-impregnation (vanadium was coated with TiO2 using incipient wetness impregnation). The removal efficiency of H2S according to the method of producing vanadium catalyst was greater in order of 10 V/TiO2 (impregnation) > 10 V/TiO2 (mixed) > V2O5 powder. The concentration of the outlet SO2 according to the removal efficiency of H2S was the highest when V2O5 powder was used (Fig. 3 ). In general, the bulk form of V2O5 powder has basic activity. VOx bond is composed of crystalline types. As bulk-type V2O5 powder suppresses the reduction ability of the catalyst and reduces oxidation performance, it has low selectivity to element S but high selectivity to SO2 [17]. Through EDS mapping (Fig. 4 ), 10 V/TiO2-impregnation had very dispersed active metal. Also, 10 V/TiO2-mix was partially formed in bulk. Since 10 V/TiO2-impregnation was made with incipient wetness impregnation, it had a highly dispersed active substance. Thus, its H2S oxidation performance was the best. Because the active substance was dispersed uniformly in the support, 10 V/TiO2-mixed showed better oxidation performance. Since 10 V/TiO2-impregnation was made with incipient wetness impregnation, it had a highly dispersed active substance. Thus, its H2S oxidation performance was the best. In a previous study it was claimed to be the dispersion limit (“monolayer”) of 6–7 atom/nm2 to avoid the formation of crystalline V2O5 and obtain molecularly dispersed vanadium oxide species depends on the surface area of the titania [49,50]. Based on results shown in Fig. 3, the V/TiO2 catalyst used later was produced by incipient wetness impregnation. When O2 reacts with H2S as a reactant at a ratio of 2:1 (H2S:O2), sulfur and water are generated. Controlling O2 in the reaction is considered important because the conversion to sulfur or SO2 varies depending on the amount of O2 participating in the reaction [14]. In this research, the conversion was the best when the ratio of O2/H2S was 0.5. However, the conversion to SO2 tended to increase rapidly. As for the conversion to element S, it was revealed that O2/H2S ratio of 0.45 could lead to high selectivity for element S but low selectivity for SO2. Therefore, the optimum O2 injection ratio was considered to be 0.45. The textural properties of the 10 V/TiO2-mix, 10 V/TiO2-impregnation, V2O5 powder were evaluated by N2 adsorption-desorption at −196 °C (Table 3 , Fig. 5 ). As the surface area increased, the pore volume decreased, and the pore diameter decreased, the V2O5/TiO2-impregnation catalyst showed a higher amount of available active sites for the selective oxidation of the H2S. To study the removal efficiency of H2S according to changes in vanadium content, performances of V/TiO2 catalysts coated with 2, 10, and 20 % of vanadium were compared. Results showed that the conversion to H2S and elemental sulfur depending on vanadium content had the order of 10 V/TiO2 > 2 V/TiO2 > 20 V/TiO2 (Fig. 6 ). SO2 was produced at the highest concentration with 20 V/TiO2 catalyst. VOx exists in three forms (monomeric, polymeric, and crystalline) depending on oxygen bond structure [51]. In general, as vanadium content increases, crystalline V2O5 is formed due to cohesion, the main cause of degradation of catalyst activity [52]. Therefore, when V/TiO2 is coated on the honeycomb, it is recommended to apply 10 V/TiO2 catalysts with high H2S oxidation performance and low SO2 production. 3.2 Effect of landfill gas composition on oxidation of H2S in V/TiO2 catalyst Landfill gas mainly consists of CH4 and CO2 with high-concentration of H2S. In this research, the performance of 10 V/TiO2 catalyst was explored based on 1 % (v/v) of H2S under the condition of rich CH4 and CO2 in landfill gas (Fig. 7 ). When CH4 (47 %) and CO2 (39 %) were injected instead of inactive gas N2, no significant change was observed in oxidation performance. H2S conversion rate was between 82 % and 85 % at a reaction temperature of 200 °C. The concentration of SO2 was rather decreased from 580 ppm to 180 ppm. For biogas containing CH4 and CO2, it has been reported that the existence of CH4 and CO2 has little effect on the performance of catalysts [17]. To evaluate the applicability of 10 V/TiO2 catalysts in various temperature ranges, the oxidation performance was evaluated by lowering the reaction temperature from 250 °C to 130 °C by 20 °C. H2S conversion and SO2 concentration were measured based on H2S 4 % (v/v) containing 47 % of CH4 and 39 % of CO2. Results are shown in Fig. 8 . Although H2S conversion was maintained at about 87 % from 150 °C to 250 °C, it decreased to below 80 % at 130 °C. The concentration of SO2 increased as the reaction temperature increased. This indicates that, when the reaction temperature on the equilibrium conversion phase of the oxidation reaction increases, the selectivity for element S declines and the selectivity for SO2 increases [53]. This research revealed that the oxidation performance of the 10 V/TiO2 catalyst itself was increased. In addition, H2S conversion was about 80 % at a reaction temperature of 130 °C, indicating that the reaction could be operated at a relatively low temperature. Considering phase equilibrium of sulfur according to temperature, the method of recovering element S is difficult to be applied at a low temperature because sulfur exists in solid from below 120 °C at 1 atm [54]. SEM and XRD analysis were performed to confirm the product after the reaction (Figs. 9 and 10 ). In SEM analysis, the surface of the catalyst was compared before and after the reaction. It was revealed that substance covering the catalyst surface was formed after the reaction. Also, XRD analysis also compared with the standard values of the orthorhombic phase of sulfur (JCPDS no. 08-0247) [55,56]. Compared to the catalyst before the reaction, the overall peak of the catalyst decreased after the reaction due to covering of the catalyst surface [57]. In addition, it was confirmed that the peak of the newly formed substance was formed on the catalyst surface after the reaction. Peaks of 23°, 27.7°, and 28.7° were formed in the range of 2θ = 23-29°, the main peak indicated by solid sulfur in the literature [58,59], directly confirming that the substance produced by the reaction was solid sulfur. This experiment suggests that the catalyst reaction in the low temperature area (130 °C) is fundamentally difficult to apply because sulfur converted after H2S oxidation remains on the catalyst surface as well. The composition of landfill gas varies depending on characteristics of local waste. However, the concentration of O2 contained in the landfill gas is generally low despite flowing in of some air during the process because the production mechanism is an anaerobic reaction. Since the SCO of H2S requires a proper O2/H2S ratio for a smooth reaction as mentioned previously, it is necessary to supply extra O2 if high-concentration H2S is generated. In this section, H2S oxidation performance was reviewed through additional O2 supply. Therefore, experiments were conducted by simulating landfill gas generated from actual landfills. Results are shown in Fig. 11 . When the landfill gas was injected into the reactor at 250 °C, it showed about 70 % of H2S removal efficiency. This meant that O2 was insufficient with O2/H2S ratio of the landfill gas at about 0.41. Therefore, the O2/H2S ratio was increased to 0.5 by injecting more O2. This resulted in about 90 % of H2S removal efficiency. In addition, as shown in Fig. 12 , a yellow layer was formed in the quartz tube. This had the same color and shape of the product in Fig. 9. It was considered to be sulfur in a solid phase. In this experiment, additional supply of O2 could favorably control the oxidation reaction. However, landfill gas contains not only H2S, but also siloxane and VOC substance [60]. This not only adversely affects operation of the pretreatment facility, but also negatively affects catalyst reaction. Thuis, it is important to study the effect of long-term exposure. 3.3 H2S oxidation performance and effect of 10 V/TiO2–coated honeycomb-type catalysts Performances of honeycomb-type catalysts were determined by CPSI. CPSI refers to the number of cells contained per square inch. The CPSI of honeycomb can be applied in various ways depending on the environment of the applied process. For example, 50 CPSI means that there are 50 cells in a 1-inch honeycomb. The greater the CPSI, the smaller the size of each cell. When the specific surface area of the catalyst increases, the pressure load also increases [61]. Accordingly, it is required to study H2S oxidation performance of honeycomb-type catalysts and CPSI that may affect process operations for practical applications. Based on the same honeycomb volume, H2S removal efficiency according to CPSI was evaluated in a honeycomb-type catalyst coated with 100 g·L−1 of 10 V/TiO2. CPSIs of the honeycomb were set to 50, 100, 200, and 300. Results revealed that the performance of the honeycomb-type catalyst increased as CPSI increased (Fig. 13 ). In particular, the performance of the honeycomb-type catalyst with 300 CPSI was very similar to that of the powder-type 10 V/TiO2 catalyst. The reason why the performance of the honeycomb-type catalyst increased as CPSI increased was that the higher the CPSI, the greater the surface area as shown in Table 1. This can be explained by increase in the number of contacts on the catalyst surface [62]. Also, as CPSI increased, performance and specific surface areas also increased. As a result of BET analysis, each value of specific surface areas in the order of 50, 100, 200, 300 CPSI was 8.47, 10.41, 10.87, 21.58 m2 g−1. Additionally, the higher the performance of the honeycomb-type catalyst, the higher the outlet SO2 concentration. SO2 was produced up to 1400 ppm at 300 CPSI. This confirms that the CPSI of honeycomb also affects the performance of H2S oxidation. When H2S oxidation performance was compared according to the amount of V/TiO2 catalyst coated, it was revealed that the honeycomb-type catalyst coated with 70 g·L−1 based on the volume of the honeycomb showed very similar H2S oxidation performance with the powder-type V/TiO2 (Fig. 14 ). It also produced less SO2 compared to powder-type V/TiO2, revealing that its selective oxidation for element S was more excellent. Therefore, when catalysts are applied to actual processes in the future, it is important to consider not only oxidation performance, but also economic feasibility and operations [63]. These results indicate that H2S oxidation performance can be controlled by the coating amount of V/TiO2 catalyst and cell size. 3.4 Durability and regeneration of honeycomb-type catalysts As for commercialization of catalysts, it is important to study the durability and regeneration in terms of actual process operations. It is known that the performance of commercial SCR catalysts degrades due to poisoning effect caused by alkaline metals, alkaline earth metals, and heavy metals and deposition of solids with time [64,65]. It is also known that the performance of catalysts for H2S oxidation is deteriorated by covering of the surface due to deposition of sulfur rather than various poisoning substances [66]. Therefore, in this research, the durability of catalysts was evaluated through long-term operations of honeycomb-type catalysts coated with 70 g·L−1 of 10 V/TiO2. The regeneration was determined by heat treatment. For honeycomb-type catalysts, 300 CPSI was used. Although heat treatment temperature should have been above 120 °C, considering phase equilibrium of sulfur, it was set to be 400 °C for smooth discharge and movement of sulfur. Although poisoning substances can be removed at higher temperatures, vanadium coated on the honeycomb can be deposited, volatilized, and melted. In addition, the crystal structure of TiO2 used as the support may be changed. Therefore, it is appropriate to perform thermal regeneration at a temperature as low as possible [67]. The regeneration of the honeycomb-type catalyst was carried out in a 400 °C of air atmosphere for 3 h. Durability evaluation showed that the honeycomb-type catalyst had 90 % H2S conversion for 24 h. The conversion gradually decreased and SO2 production increased from 27 h (Fig. 15 ). The time when regeneration was required was set as the point at which the performance deteriorated. The 1st regeneration was performed after 27 h. After the 1st regeneration, the performance of the honeycomb-type catalyst recovered again. However, the performance after the 1st regeneration decreased to 20 % after 12 h. The same procedure was repeated to perform regeneration twice. The rate of the performance decrease after regeneration gradually increased. After the 2nd regeneration, the performance decreased to 10 % after 6 h. It decreased to 10 % at 4 h after the 3rd regeneration. It was confirmed that the more the regeneration, the more the overall amount of SO2 production. The initial SO2 concentration was 800 ppm. It was 1600 ppm after the 1st regeneration and 1800 ppm after the 3rd regeneration. SEM/EDS analysis was performed to check the surface of the catalyst before and after the reaction and after the regeneration. As shown in Figs. 8 and 9, it was confirmed that the substance on the surface after H2S oxidation reaction was solid sulfur. Likewise, as shown in Fig. 16 , granular sulfur deposits were formed on the surface of the catalyst after the reaction. They were removed after regeneration. In addition, EDS analysis revealed that the content of elemental sulfur on the surface was 0.28 wt% in uncontaminated catalyst, 6.63 wt% in the catalyst after the reaction, and 0.40 wt% in the catalyst after the regeneration (Fig. 17 ). It was believed that the results may be due to the reduction of specific surface area by aging [68,69]. The specific surface area was gradually decreased by sintering effect according to the regeneration and found that the produced sulfur is bonded with the surface of the catalyst. After evaluating the durability and regeneration of honeycomb-type catalysts with landfill gas for practical application, results revealed that the accumulation of sulfur deposits had a great effect on the performance of honeycomb-type catalysts and that there was a limitation to the number of catalyst regeneration. Therefore, it is necessary to study various regeneration methods for effective regeneration of honeycomb-type catalysts. 4 Conclusions Vanadium catalysts showed the best performance when manufactured with incipient wetness impregnation. The optimum vanadium content was 10 %. The proper O2/H2S ratio to control the product’s selectivity in the selective oxidation of H2S was 0.45, at which minimum SO2 was generated. CH4 and CO2 accountings for 90 % of landfill gas had no significant effect on H2S oxidation performance. Oxidation performance of H2S was excellent at a temperature of between 150 and 250 °C. It started to decrease from temperature below 130 °C. As a result of comparing oxidation performance of honeycomb-type catalysts according to CPSI, 300 CPSI with high specific surface area showed the best performance. When considering selective oxidation with element S, it is proper to coat the honeycomb with 70 g·L−1 of V/TiO2 catalyst. Durability evaluation through a long-time operation of honeycomb-type catalysts revealed that oxidation performance was about 90 % for 24 h. The performance increased after regeneration. However, even after attempting thermal regeneration, there was still some sulfur remained on the surface of the catalyst. Since continuous deposition of sulfur could lead to performance deterioration, it is necessary to develop methods to effectively control it. This research confirms that honeycomb-type catalysts are applicable to high-concentration H2S removal in the actual process. coredata.dc:description: In this research, selective catalytic oxidation was applied to remove high-concentration hydrogen sulfide in landfill gas. The removal efficiency of H2S was the best with V/TiO2 catalyst produced by wet impregnation among. The optimum vanadium content was 10 %. In addition, selective conversion to elemental sulfur and generation of SO2 could be controlled by adjusting O2/H2S ratio. The larger the cell per square inch that affected the performance of the honeycomb-type catalyst, the greater the removal efficiency of H2S according to increase in specific surface area. An analysis of long-term performance of the honeycomb-type catalyst with landfill gas including CH4 and CO2 revealed that more than 90 % of H2S was removed. In addition, the performance of the catalyst could be recovered by thermal regeneration. Considering that the performance of a catalyst can be recovered for durability and regeneration, V/TiO2 coated honeycomb-type catalyst can be used in the actual process.
coredata.dc:title: Application and regeneration of honeycomb-type catalysts for the selective catalytic oxidation of H2S to sulfur from landfill gas
